proof.text: Let  be the straight line which produces with a rational area a medial whole, and let  be an annex to ; therefore ,  are straight lines incommensurable in square which fulfil the given conditions. [elem.10.77]
I say that no other straight line can be annexed to  which fulfils the same conditions.
For, if possible, let  be so annexed; therefore ,  are also straight lines incommensurable in square which fulfil the given conditions. [elem.10.77]

Since then, as in the preceding cases, the excess of the squares on ,  over the squares on ,  is also the excess of twice the rectangle ,  over twice the rectangle , , while twice the rectangle ,  exceeds twice the rectangle ,  by a rational area, for both are rational, therefore the squares on ,  also exceed the squares on ,  by a rational area: which is impossible, for both are medial. [elem.10.26]

Therefore no other straight line can be annexed to  which is incommensurable in square with the whole and which with the whole fulfils the aforesaid conditions; therefore only one straight line can be so annexed. Q. E. D.
